title: 110_hr5962
content: The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" is a temporary deduction for certain mortgage counseling under section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows individuals to deduct up to $500 for qualified mortgage counseling provided by an FHA-accredited organization before obtaining a loan on their principal residence. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows a deduction for mortgage counseling obtained before a loan is issued on the taxpayer's principal residence. The deduction is not allowed for counseling on loans not secured by the taxpayer's principal residence. The deduction is not allowed for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2012. The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" allows a deduction for mortgage counseling obtained before a loan is issued on the taxpayer's principal residence. The deduction is applicable to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. Additionally, a temporary deduction for upside-down mortgages is introduced under section 225 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction allowed for mortgage counseling obtained before a loan is issued on the taxpayer's principal residence is 20% of the excess acquisition indebtedness over the valuation of the residence, limited to $5,000 per year. Fraudulently obtained mortgages are not eligible for this deduction. The deduction for mortgage counseling before a loan is issued on the taxpayer's principal residence is limited to $5,000 per year. Fraudulently obtained mortgages are not eligible for this deduction. Subsection (a) of section 62 of the Tax Code is amended to include a new paragraph regarding upside-down mortgages. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part VII of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Tax Code. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. A new section is added to the Internal Revenue Code for a temporary credit for certain home purchases. A temporary credit is allowed for individuals purchasing a qualified principal residence, equal to 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas). The credit is divided equally over two taxable years starting from the year of purchase. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is divided equally over two taxable years, with limitations on the date of purchase and income levels. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income, with limitations on the date of purchase and income levels. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year, with limitations on income levels. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income for the taxable year. The credit allowed for any taxable year cannot exceed the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the sum of other allowable credits for the year. Additionally, the credit is a one-time only benefit for an individual and their spouse. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is a one-time benefit for an individual and their spouse. If the credit is used for one residence, no credit can be claimed for another residence in the same taxable year by the same individual or their spouse. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is a one-time benefit for individuals or married couples. If the credit is used for one residence, no credit can be claimed for another residence in the same taxable year. A qualified principal residence is defined as any residence purchased to be the principal residence of the buyer. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is a one-time benefit for individuals or married couples. A qualified principal residence is any residence purchased to be the buyer's principal residence. No credit is allowed if a credit is already claimed under another section. If the residence is disposed of or not occupied as the principal residence within 24 months, recapture may be required. In case of certain dispositions or failure to occupy the qualified principal residence within 24 months of purchase, the remaining portion of the credit allowed shall be disallowed in the taxable year of disposition or non-occupation. Special rules apply for joint purchases, including married individuals filing separately. Special rules apply for joint purchases of qualified principal residences, including married individuals filing separately and unmarried individuals. The credit allowed under subsection (a) will be allocated among individuals in a manner prescribed by the Secretary. The credit for purchasing a qualified principal residence is allocated among unmarried individuals as prescribed by the Secretary, with a total limit of $7,000. Rules similar to section 1400C apply for purchase and reporting requirements. Basis adjustment is made if a credit is allowed for the purchase. Rules similar to section 1400C apply for reporting requirements. Basis of the residence is reduced by the credit amount allowed under this section. Conforming amendments are made to sections 24, 25, and 25B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including sections 25E, 25B, and others. Section 1016 is amended to include provisions from section 25E(g). Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include adding provisions from section 25E(g) to section 1016 and updating section 1400C(d)(2) to include references to section 25E. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections. SEC. 25E provides a credit for certain home purchases, effective for purchases in taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Additionally, SEC. 5 offers a temporary additional standard deduction for real property taxes for nonitemizers. The amendment adds a real property tax deduction for taxable years 2008 and 2009, capped at $500 ($1,000 for joint filers). This deduction applies to eligible State and local real property taxes paid by the taxpayer. The real property tax deduction for taxable years 2008 and 2009 is capped at $500 ($1,000 for joint filers) for eligible State and local real property taxes paid by the taxpayer. The real property tax deduction is capped at $500 ($1,000 for joint filers) for eligible State and local real property taxes paid by the taxpayer, with an effective date for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 6 amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude unemployment compensation from gross income for individuals in 2008 and 2009. This exclusion applies to amounts received after December 31, 2007.
